newsitem.title: ITALY: Georgia's Shevardnadze hails NATO compromise.
newsitem.headline: Georgia's Shevardnadze hails NATO compromise.

text.p: Georgian President Eduard Shevardnadze, a former Soviet foreign minister and key figure in reforms that helped end the Cold War, said on Thursday the historic deal between NATO and Russia was the compromise needed.

"When the dispute (over enlargement) began I said, and I say again now, that there was no need to dramatise the situation, just to find a compromise," Shevardnadze told a news conference in Rome where he is on three-day visit.
"I believe we have found that compromise," he said.

NATO and Moscow struck a landmark agreement on Wednesday on a new political and military relationship allowing the U.S.-led alliance to proceed with plans for eastward expansion into former communist Europe. In return, Moscow gets a permanent voice at the centre of Europe's security order.
Georgia won independence from the Soviet Union in 1991 and Shevardnazde, 69, has been its leader since 1992, although he did not have the title president at first.

Shevardnadze met Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi for talks on improving bilateral relations and the two countries signed 10 accords on political, economic, investment, transport, science, tourism, naval, immigration and defence issues.
